text: CAROL PETERSEN (70s) wakes up to her alarm, the clock dig showing 6:00 sharp. A golden retriever DOG is at the foot her bed. He lifts his head as she responds to the alarm. Carol sits up in bed and the dog follows her movements, turning his head, both of them moving slowly. She pets th dog.
Hey, Hazel. You sleep any better last night? INT. CAROL'S HOUSE - SIDE DOOR ENTRY —- MORNING 1A Carol removes Hazel’s leash from a coat hook and attaches to Hazel’s collar before going out the door.

Carol, looking groggy but dressed in sharp-looking joggin clothes, walks the dog through her neighborhood. The dog hesitant and Carol needs to cajole the dog into motion wi each stop. Carol’s neighbor MIKE (late 70s/early 80s) approaches, walking his dog, and stops. The two dogs nuzzle each othe in a familiar way.
Hey you.
Hey Mike.
How's Hazel?
Don’t know. I don’t like the looks of him this morning. He's been having some rough nights. Walking funny.
Goddamned cancer.
He doesn’t complain. He acts like nothing’s going on.  10
He sure looks chipper right now.
He’s chatting with his buddy.
(pausing to look at Carol) You're his buddy, Carol.

We see the inside of Carol’s home, which is extremely cle and tidy. We see some photographs in her living room: Car and a handsome MAN, at a table, smiling. Carol and the sa man on a boat. And a young, beaming Carol in a black and white photo, circa 1960s, singing in a folk duo. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - MORNING 4 Carol sits at a table drinking coffee. She has a New York Times in her hands. Hazel is in the room with her, standi facing the wall, wagging his tail while he eats his breakfast. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - MORNING 5 Carol takes some pills and vitamins with water.
EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 7 Carol waters some of her plants. Hazel sleeps poolside.
EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 9 Carol eats a sandwich by her pool. She gives Hazel a piec of sandwich.
Carol hits a ball with a club while her friend SALLY (65) watches.
Nice shot, Carol.
Carol plays bridge as has a laugh with a GROUP OF FRIENDS
Carol sits on the bed and watches TV with a glass of wine Hazel lies next to her in bed.

Carol wakes up before the alarm goes off, as if she’s hea something. The clock says 5:20. Hazel is not in bed with her. Carol gets out of bed and goes looking for the dog, calling for him. We stay on the empty bed.
Hazel? Hazel? Carol sighs as she finds the dog.
Hey, Hazel. You not feeling so good?

Carol sits in a chair beside her dog in a euthanasia room Carol’s eyes are red-rimmed, exhausted. She leans over Ha and embraces him, stroking his fur. She takes his paw, wh is wrapped in medical tape and fitted with an IV catheter
I guess this is goodbye, boy, but the hell if I know what to say.
18 CLOSE UP on the dog’s face. The dog pants and his eyes ar glazed over.

I should say you’re going to a better place, shouldn't I? Nothing but doggies. (pauses) Maybe you don’t wanna hear about that. Maybe you better just wait and see. (she takes a deep breath) I’m just gonna sit with you as long as they let me. Carol sits in silence and looks fondly at the dog. A VET opens the door and Carol looks up. Carol knows it’s time.
CLOSE UP on Carol’s face as the Vet administers the injections, which we hear but do not see. While the Vet speaks, Carol pets Hazel.

(softly) I'm giving him the sedative now. He may close his eyes. (pauses) Okay. Now he’s very relaxed. (pauses) I’m going to inject the pentobarbital. This will stop his heart. After a long pause the Vet puts on a stethoscope and list for a heartbeat.

His heart has stopped. (pauses) I’m very sorry. Take as much time as you need. The VET leaves the room. Carol sits with Hazel. INT. CAROL’S CAR (EXT. ANIMAL HOSPITAL) - DAY 18 Carol, wearing sunglasses to hide tears, heads to hear ca and gets in. She starts her car. “I Never Dreamed” by The Cookies is on the radio. Carol lets it play and drives of  19 20 21 22 23 24 25

Carol drives down a quaint neighborhood street. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - STREET - DAY 20 Carol pulls next to her house. INT. CAROL’S CAR (EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - STREET) - DAY 21 Carol sits in her car. “I Never Dreamed” continues to pla Carol just sits there, listening to the song.
Carol walks in her house. She has Hazel’s leash in her ha She looks at it and hangs it up by the door.
Carol pours herself a glass of white wine. She pauses, th adds a bit more. She has a sip and takes a deep breath.

Carol is sitting in her living room. She has another sip her wine. She looks around. The house feels big and empty All the lights are off. Carol hears a rustling nearby. She looks over, then stand and takes a few tentative steps toward the sound. At firs she sees nothing, and then sees the snout of a small anim poking out from behind a cabinet. It stops moving at the sound of Carol’s footsteps. Carol stares in shock, unable speak. The animal then comes out from the cabinet and scuttles along the wall. It is a RAT. Carol screams at the top of her lungs and runs out of the living room. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 25 Carol runs to the back doors and opens them, finally gett outside. Carol, shaken by the whole incident, looks in th door to see if she can see the rat.  26 EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY - LATER 26 Carol, having nodded off on her outdoor couch, wakes up. looks over to see LLOYD (early 30s), a pool guy, standing there with all of his pool cleaning gear. He has a pair o headphones on. He pulls the headphones down around his ne when he sees Carol staring at him.
Afternoon. (pauses) You okay?
Okay?
You seemed...
What? Are you saying you thought I was dead?
No, not that. Sorry. Lloyd begins unloading his gear by the pool, trying to av the conversation.
Because I’m an old person and I had my eyes closed.
I was just making sure you were okay.
No, I’m not okay. I’m terrible. Lloyd just stares at her, unsure of what to say next.
Who are you? It was always another guy. Richie? Lloyd has already moved to the edge of the pool and begun setting up his cleaning gear.
Richie, uh, moved on. He had a difference of opinion with the owners. I’m the new guy.

Okay, clean away, new guy. She begins to open the door to go back inside, then hesit and shuts it. Lloyd puts his headphones on and begins assembling his gear to clean the pool, then pauses and removes the headphones.
You don’t look that old, by the way. I mean, I wasn’t worried because you look old.
(distracted) You always gotta assume the worst. Don’t worry about it. Lloyd puts his headphones back on. Carol peers into the house and then looks back at Lloyd.
Um... excuse me? Lloyd removes his headphones.
What’s that?
I’m sorry. I... Can I ask you a favor?
Carol waits on pins and needles while Lloyd searches for rat.
Do you see anything?
I... do not.
Keep looking. Check behind the curtains.
Sorry, I didn’t see it. Maybe it’s gone.
Oh god. He’s probably going to reappear the second you leave.
Maybe you should call, like, an exterminator? Carol gives him a look and cautiously enters the house.
I can’t imagine where it came from. I haven’t even seen a mouse in years. I think my dog must've kept them away. But a rat... it was black. Like a bad omen.
So where’s the dog?
(blankly) I had to put him down today.
Oh. Jeez, I’m sorry. Carol doesn’t respond.
I should probably, uh, get back to work.
Yes, I’m sorry. Thank you... (waiting for his name)
Lloyd.
Lloyd. I’m Carol. Lloyd nods and half smiles.
Uh... I’1l be right outside if the rat comes back. Carol nods and Lloyd heads out.  28 29 30 31 32
Carol is reading at her dining room table with a new glas wine. Lloyd knocks on the door.
(through the window) All set! Carol smiles and waves. As Lloyd walks away she just sits there, alone in the house.

Carol wakes up to her alarm, the clock digits showing 6:0 sharp. INT. CAROL'S HOUSE - SIDE ENTRY —- MORNING 31 Carol heads for the door, dressed in her usual walking outfit. Carol walks out the door, leaving Hazel’s leash i it’s spot on the wall.
Carol walks along the sidewalk. Mike approaches with his
You’re gonna tell me some bad news, aren’t you. When I didn’t see you guys yesterday... Carol, petting his dog, nods.
Yep.
I’m sorry, Carol. It’s hard. You should be thankful that you were able to do that for him. Carol says nothing. She isn’t choking up but she doesn’t to talk about it.
Carol, if you ever need anything...  33 34 35 36 37 10.
Thanks Mike. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - DAY 33 Carol sits at her table drinking coffee with a copy of Th New York Times nearby. She has the Yellow Pages open to a “Exterminators” page.
Carol takes some pills and vitamins with water. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 35 Carol waters some of her plants by her pool. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 36 Carol eats a salad by her pool.
Carol and the EXTERMINATOR walk through the kitchen towar the living room.
I suspect this was a black rat or what we call a roof rat. Very common in Southern California.
Where do you think it came from?
They're everywhere. They live in the trees... they’re all over the city.
Okay.
You'd never seen signs of them before? Rodent droppings, gnaw marks on bags of pet food, anything like that? They love dog food.  38 39 40 4l 42 43 11.
No.

And you haven’t seen it since yesterday? Carol shakes her head. EXTERMINATOR (CONT’D) Well, I have my doubts that the rodent is inhabiting your house. I checked the whole perimeter for points of entry and I’m not seeing any holes and there are no signs of colonization. I’ll set a few traps to make sure but I think what we have here is an isolated incident. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL AREA - DAY 38 Carol opens a garbage can lid and throws away a half-empt bag of dog food.
Carol watches some TV with a glass of wine.
Carol wakes up to her alarm, 6:00. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - DAY 43 Carol sits at a table reading The New York Times. The pho rings.
Carol walks into her kitchen and picks up the cordless an looks at the caller ID with a puzzled expression, then presses the button and puts the phone to her ear.  12.
Hello?
Hi Mom. It’s Katherine.
I saw your name on the thing... is everything okay?
Just checking in... I heard about Hazel, Mom.
How on earth did you hear that?
Rona sent me an e-mail.
Since when do you and Rona e-mail?
We e-mail, mom. We’re friends on Facebook. I’ve known her my whole life.
You never e-mail me.
You don’t ever use the computer.
And you e-mail Rona of all people? How did she find out?
She didn't say. Mom, I’m just... so sorry. It’s just terrible news. What happened?
When I got up yesterday he was just... he couldn’t walk. I carried him to the car myself. They said the cancer had spread everywhere. His spine. You could tell... looking at his eyes... it was time.
You didn’t ask for help?  13.
Why. What for?
Should you even be carrying things like that...? Heavy things...
He was a dog, Kath. Not a thing. And it was five in the morning.
I just thought you had a weight limit, after the back injury, when was that... didn’t you have surgery?
No, I didn’t have surgery.
You didn’t? I thought - your back -
I see a chiropractor. I also play golf, I swim, I carry my own groceries. I clean this house. I... Not that you’d know, anyway. When were you last here? Right after 9/11 I think it was?
I've been there since then.
No, no... I think that was the last time. You couldn’t stand the smell or something and so you came out here.
Mom. I came down there to be with you. It was like going through what happened with Dad all over again -
You spent two weeks watching CNN and talking to your boyfriend on your cell phone and never the left the house.
Everybody was that way when that happened.  44 45 46 14.
Well, that was the last time you were here. Every other time I’ve come out there. Did you ever even meet Hazel? Silence on the line.
(conciliatory) Okay, never mind - I don’t... I don’t mean to be... how did you put it? “Guilt tripping” you?
Okay. I’ve gotta go, Mom. I’m sorry about Hazel. I hope you’re doing okay.
The house feels empty without him but I’m okay. Thanks.

Okay. Love you. The phone line clicks as Katherine hangs up on the other Carol looks at the phone and clicks it off and sets it on counter. A beat later the phone rings again and she picks up on the first ring.
(irritated) What.... Yes it is.... (long pause, then quietly) Thank you. Yes. I’1l be by later.
Carol exits the hospital carrying a paper bag.
Carol browses the shelves, picking up bottles and lifting pair of reading glasses to her eyes to read the labels. T scene has a tone of eavesdropping on Carol.
May I help you find something?  15.
I’m not sure. Store clerk looks at Carol patiently.
I just want to be sure I’m getting enough of everything.
Are you taking supplements now?
I take a multivitamin... I take vitamin C. Calcium. I take some things a friend gave me... kelp?
(patiently) Do you have any health issues you want to address? Carol shakes her head vigorously.
No, no, it’s not...
Okay, so let’s look at a few more basics. Do you take any magnesium?
I’m not sure.

Magnesium is a very good anti- inflammatory, very good for the smooth muscles and the joints. It’s a good all-around anti-aging supplement. Store Clerk removes a bottle from the shelf and shows it Carol.

This one is very popular. Carol takes the bottle and looks at the clerk over her reading glasses. While they are talking, a MAN (70s) is standing down the aisle from them with an unlit cigar in mouth, listening but not looking at them.  47 48 49 50 51 52 16.
What about... are you doing a probiotic?
Carol continues to look around, her basket now full of various bottles. She picks up a bottle and inspects it. T Man with the unlit cigar comes up to her as she browses.
(pointing at bottle) You don’t need all that. Carol looks up to the Man. CIGAR MAN (CONT’D) You're just right the way you are. The Cigar Man walks away and Carol just watches him go.

Carol comes home with shopping bags in hand. She places t on the counter. She reaches into a paper bag and pulls ou cardboard box. She inspects it. CLOSE UP on the top of th box is a sticker that says “HAZEL: CHERISHED PET OF CAROL PETERSEN.” She opens the box and pulls out a keepsake tin INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY 50 Carol heads into the living room. She puts Hazel’s ashes the keepsake tin next to a very nice vase above her fireplace.
Carol's car pulls into a retirement community. The sign r “ROYAL OAKS.”
Carol walks through the retirement community. Older peopl walk around, mostly in groups and pairs. A few people sit lawn chairs outside of their apartments, chatting.  53 17.

Carol sits at a card table playing bridge with three frie RONA, GEORGINA, and SALLY, all in their early to mid-70s. hand has been dealt and the four women are holding their cards and rearranging them in their hands. Three of them are drinking white wine, with the exception Sally who is drinking a can of Budweiser.
Rona, did you see Jerry today? At the pool?
Jerry who?
There’s only the one Jerry.
There’s three Jerrys!
(counting on her fingers) Jerry Davis, Gerry Phillips, and Jerry Li.
See?
Gerry Phillips is Gerry with a G, though. Does he count?
Do you know who he was with?
Which one?
Jerry Davis, for Christ’s sake.
Are we playing cards, girls? Your bid, Georgina.
One spade.
Pass.  18.
One no trump.
Pass.
Two no trump.
Pass.
(thinking about it) Three no trump.
I'm feeling good tonight, girls. You guys are not winning tonight, I can tell you that. Sally laughs.
Pass.
Pass. The girls start arranging their cards.
So who the who hell was he with?
Who?
Jerry Davis.
Oh right. Jerry was with Karen. And I could've sworn she was doing you- know-what to him in the pool.
Sally!
Not sex, Georgie. I think she was just giving him a little tug. Carol and Rona laugh. Georgina is shocked.  19.
The language, Sally!
What language?
(shivering) “Tug.”
How is that language? I said “tug.” I didn’t say she was “jerking him off.” Jeez...
I don’t like that kinda talk.
You're so sensitive, Georgie.
I'd just rather not hear about Jerry Davis’ habits in the pool.
That pool. It’s disgusting. Too many people are in that pool.
I love that pool.
God knows what’s in that pool.
It doesn't seem particularly clean.
Like your pool’s a day spa.
I have it cleaned once a week.
Carol, when are you gonna move in here? A lady just passed on two cottages over. God rest her soul.
That reminds me - they have new brochures. I want you to see the new brochures, Carol.  20.
I don’t want to see the new brochures. I already saw the old brochures.
I‘1l bring some by this week.
Yeah, Carol. You’re missing out on all the action.
I’m very happy with my house, thank you.
But that pool, Carol.
What about my pool?
You're all alone there! You could slip and fall and no one would be around to help you. You could drown in that pool.
Well, at least it’d be clean. The girls laugh. Some card playing.
Carol, how's Hazel been feeling lately? Carol looks at her.

Hazel... He, uh... (looks at Rona, then looks down at her cards) I had to put Hazel down. All at once GEORGINA and SALLY put their cards down and u hushed apologies, “Oh, Carol,” “For Christ’s sake, why di you tell us,” etc.
When?
A couple days ago.  21.
That’s terrible, Carol.
(to Rona) Don’t act so surprised.
What are you talking about?
Don’t play dumb, Rona. Kath told me you told her. How'd you find out anyway?
Mike told me.
The guy with the dog? Your neighbor?
(to Rona) Well, aren’t you just cozy with everyone? Rona is hurt by this. Sally sees it and jumps in.
She's just upset, Rona.
Of course she is. We all loved Hazel, Carol.
(to Carol) How are you holding up?
I'm fine. I’m sorry, Ro.
To hell with the card game. We should get good and drunk tonight. (standing) I’m getting another. And I got some of that medical marijuana...
(to Carol) What are you going to do?  22.
What do you mean?
I don’t know... are you getting another dog?
She's in mourning, Georgina. You can’t just get a new dog right after. It’s not like her car died.
I couldn't get another dog after my last one passed. It’s just too hard to replace them.

I just know you loved that boy so much. Carol doesn’t respond. The ladies look at each other. GEORGINA (CONT’D) We should do something. We should have a memorial or something. I can talk to my pastor.
Or maybe we can treat you to a nice dinner out someplace.

Look... there’s nothing left to do. He had a good life. Even the cancer didn’t bother him. So I don’t let it bother me either. I’m fine. Really. I’m gonna play some golf, do our bridge game on Wednesdays, try to live a bit longer, and God willing I don’t get the big A... (shrugs ) ...and maybe someday I’1l get another dog.
Just a dog?
Don’t start with that.
What?  23.
The dating talk. The second husband talk. You couldn’t pay me.
But they do pay you. When they die.
Not always.
And who's saying husband?
Maybe you could date somebody.
Maybe I could stick a fork in my eye.
(to Georgina) Like you've dated since Gary passed.
Once you’ve had the best, who cares about the rest.
Yeah, Rona. Not once you’ve had the best you go out and get another one and then another one and another one...
I’ve only been married three times!
Yeah, only three.
I’m with Georgina. I’m not interested and that’s that.
Jeez, Carol, come on. Don’t you ever think about it? Just somebody to go out with once in a while... What about Mike?
What about him?  24.
He’s cute. Seems like a nice guy.
I don’t know. Isn’t Mike a little...old?
I’m not... I’m not interested in anyone right now...
You're in that big house. All alone. We worry about you.
I’m fine.
Guys ask about you all the time, Carol. You’re a beautiful woman! I can hook you up. I know everyone here.
Like it’s that simple. If it were that simple...
What? You mean you gotta put out?
(shivering again) Like with Jerry in the pool.
That’s not what she means.
I just mean I don’t like my life all complicated. Hazel’s gone, but I like my life the way it is. It’s easy. I know where everything is. Carol looks at everyone. Everyone is looking at her.
Never mind. Are we playing cards, girls? Let’s play some cards.
The alarm goes off. Carol wakes up and gets out of bed.  55 56 25.
CLOSE ON: a ball on a tee. A club hits the ball. Carol watches her shot as it drives down the fairway. She clearly knows what she’s doing with a golf club. Sally is watching as well.
What a shot, Carol! Wow.
Sally puts and misses. Carol stands on the green nearby.
(after missing shot) Let’s just have the maximum shot count be ten, for Christ’s sake.
The shot count is however many strokes it took you to get the ball in the hole.
(walking to her ball) Golf talk is so sexual-sounding isn’t it? Balls, holes, strokes...
Just count up your shots, Sally. And be honest.
What is this, the PGA?
Yeah, the senior-senior tour. Sally laughs and puts again. She sinks the put.
That means I scored a thirteen on this one...
Oh fine. Max score can be ten.
That’s my girl.  57
A bunch of elderly people are sitting around having and enjoying themselves. Sally is at a table with Carol after their game.
You want a drink?
It’s early. And I'm driving.
I didn’t hear a no. A WAITRESS approaches.

A Bud and a glass of chardonnay for this one. Thanks, dear. 26. 57 drinks As Sally orders, Carol looks out the window to see the CI MAN from the vitamin store talking to a few gentlemen at table on the patio. He still has an unlit cigar in his mo and seems to be in charge of the conversation. After the Waitress leaves Sally turns around and spots wh Carol is looking at.
He’s handsome.
What?
That guy.
Which one? The Cigar Man laughs and has a sip of his whiskey. looks at Carol as if to say, “You know which one.”
I've seen him before. He talked to me at the store the other day.
Really? He talked to you.
Yeah... Sally
What did he say?
Something about I’m just fine the way I am...
Are you kidding me?
I don’t remember.
Oh my god. He’s sexy, Carol. He must be new. I can find out. Sally stands to head over and Carol stops her, making her back down.
Don’t go over there.
Look at you, like a nervous schoolgirl. What are you afraid of? Carol just makes a disapproving face.
Why don’t you come with me tomorrow night to this speed dating thing -
I’m not doing that.
C’mon, Carol. They do it right inside the clubhouse. It’1l be good for you. It’s fun.
I’ll bet.

You meet some fellas, you talk a little. It’s not even dating. It’s just socializing. It’s no big deal. (pointing to the Cigar Man) Maybe he’1l be there.  58 59 60 61 28. Carol looks up to see the Cigar Man looking at her. They eyes for a moment and then the Waitress comes with drinks Carol looks away. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 58 Carol has a glass of wine by her pool. It’s clear that sh had a few since her date with Sally. She notices somethin her pool and heads over. She looks in the pool and sees t the automatic cleaning device is not moving. She makes a face.
Carol is on the phone.
Okay.... Thank you. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 60 The cleaning device is back in the pool, roving around.
Like new.
Thank you. What was the problem?
Um... They tend not to work so well when they come unplugged. Carol shakes her head, knowing how silly the problem was.
Ah...
You mind if I use your bathroom?

Lloyd comes out of the bathroom and sees Carol's pictures focuses on the one of her in a folk band. He looks more closely to see a YOUNG CAROL with a HANDSOME MAN in a bla and white photo from the sixties. They have instruments i their hands.
Long time ago. 29. Lloyd looks up to see Carol staring at the photo with him
Oh, sorry.
It’s fine.
You were a musician? Carol nods her head.
I was in a folk duo. That was in New York, a million years ago. We used to play in the Village. I sang.
That your husband? CLOSE ON: The photo and the handsome man with his arm aro Young Carol. Their pose and look of contentment suggest t they are together.
No. That’s John.
Oh.
My husband came later. Bill. Carol indicates another photo, the one we saw earlier of Carol and an older man, their arms around each other, smiling.
I used to be in a band...
Oh?
I sang, too. If you can call it that.
Where were you in a band?  30.
Austin. I just moved back here, SO...
What brought you back?
I grew up in the Valley. Austin didn’t work out.
(knowingly) I’m sure you're better off without her.
Right now it feels like it’s the other way around. (smiling) You're pretty smart for an old lady.
You have family here?
Yeah. I’m staying with my mom. Carol looks at him as if reassessing him while trying not appear to be doing so. He’s a little old to be living bac home. LLOYD (CONT’D) Temporarily.
Friends?
Not really. Not anymore, no.
You want a drink? I was about to open a bottle of wine. Well, another bottle.
I’m still on the clock.
Oh come on. My dog just died. Pretend to have a drink with me.  62 31. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - DAY 62 Carol pops open a bottle and begins pouring Lloyd a glass
You want just a little or you want the full treatment?
Fill ‘er up. She does the same for herself and lifts her glass.
Cheers, Lloyd.
Cheers. They touch glasses and have a sip. Lloyd shakes his head, enjoying the wine.
This is really good.
I think so, too. So what kind of music do you sing?
The closest I get to singing anymore is karaoke night at the bar.
Huh.
But lately I’ve been writing some songs.
So you’re a songwriter?
No... but I studied poetry in college. This is sort of the same thing.
You mean you went to school to write poetry?  32.
Yeah. B.F.A.
Bet your parents loved you for that.
Yeah. Hence the pool guy getup.
No one’s hiring poets, huh?
Not currently. Not for like the past ten years. Lloyd smiles. There’s an awkward silence.
But someday I’1l have a lot of good poems about... pools. Carol laughs.
I bet you will.
But it seems like - I mean, you were in a real group.
For a bit, yeah. That gentleman in the picture played guitar.
The one who’s not your husband.
Right. John.
John was pretty handsome.
He certainly had a way about him...
You divorced, or?

My husband? He died.  63 33. They each have another sip of wine. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - EVENING 63 Time has passed and another bottle has been opened. Carol Lloyd are both a bit tipsy. They share a big laugh.
Well, I guess they set it up so you meet a new person every few minutes or something. It sounds awful.
Well, it’s an experience, right?
I don’t know.
It might be fun. Why not? Carol thinks it over and has another sip of wine.
(to herself, tipsy) Yeah, why not... Lloyd smiles at Carol.
(checking his phone) I gotta run. Got to meet my mom for dinner.
Oh sure. Sorry I kept you.
Are you kidding? I had a great time. You’re a good drinking buddy.
You're sweet to say that.
(going to gather his gear) I’m not just saying it. Carol smiles while Lloyd goes to gather his gear. As he’s getting it together he looks back at Carol.
Hey, what happened to that rat?  64 34.
It... left. I think. The guy says it was an “isolated incident.” Whatever that means. Lloyd nods. There is some silence between them.
You know, do you wanna... hang out some time? Carol looks at Lloyd.
Not like that. I mean... Lloyd gestures helplessly.
Like this. But not here. I mean we should go out. Carol raises her eyebrows.
Not... not... go out. I just mean, if you're interested, maybe we could go do karaoke or something? I’d love to see you get up there and knock ‘em dead. Carol laughs.
We'll see.
Okay. Cool. Lloyd heads out. Carol sits for a beat and then finishes wine by the pool.

CLOSE ON: A paper flyer that says “Speed Dating - This Wa with an arrow. Carol and Sally enter the common room.
